Original question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: I protest against the method of distributing sugar in certain parts of Taomania. For many years, it has been the practice of the Colonial Sugar Refining Company Limited to deliver sugar from Melbourne to ports on the north-west coast of Tasmania, and supplies from Sydney to Hobart and Launceston. Fremantle and Launceston are the only ports in Australia that are classed as capital cities apart from the recognized capital cities. I urge that the ports of Devonport and Burnie also be included in that category. It should be realized that there are many ports in Tasmania that serve large adjoining districts and these, too, could be used for the discharge of sugar from the mainland. Supplies of sugar from Melbourne to the ports of the north-west coast of Tasmania were substantially reduced recently. A reduction of supplies in Melbourne by 25 per cent. means a similar reduction of supplies for the ports on the north-west coast, and it has not been possible to obtain sugar from Sydney for them. The practice of supplying them from Melbourne has evidently been followed for many years by the Colonial Sugar Refining Company Limited, but I consider that it should be varied, because it is unfair that the north-west of Tasmania should experience a shortage of sugar when stocks have been available in Sydney, and, what is more important, hipping has been available to transport it to Tasmania. Recently, one of the mining towns on the west coast of Tasmania was in a desperate position. The stocks of white and brown sugar, and even the black stuff that may be regarded as raw sugar, were exhausted. The people in that community also had no dried milk, and were not able to obtain fresh milk. I hope that the Government will investigate that problem of distribution. I had intended to move an amendment with the object of having Devonport and Burnie classed as capital city ports, but if I can obtain an assurance from the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Mr. Erie J. Harrison), who is in charge of the bill, that those ports, and possibly others in Tasmania, will be supplied with sugar from Melbourne and Sydney, I shall not proceed with it.
Does the honorable member propose to move the amendment that he has mentioned?
I have not moved the amendment, because I expect to obtain the assurance for which I have asked.

talker.role: Vice-President of the Executive Council and Minister for Defence Production
talker.name: HARRISON,Eric John
Mr. ERIC J. HARRISON

talk.start.para: The honorable member for Darwin (Mr. Luck) has asked for an assurance that additional shipments of sugar will be sent to the Tasmanian ports of Devonport and Burnie. The honorable member, who is very diligent in looking after the interest of the people of the north-west coast of Tasmania, has spoken to me at some length about this matter. I am well aware of the problem that confronts him and those who live in that area. It is true that in the agreement certain provincial cities in Australia have been placed on the same basis as have the capital cities as regards both distribution and price. Launceston and Fremantle fall into that category. Whether Burnie and Devonport can also be included in that category is a matter for determination by the Queensland Government and the Queensland Sugar Board. 1 assure the honorable member that the Government will make representations to the Queensland Government and to the board with a view to making arrangements to ensure that the requirements of Burnie and Devonport shall be met.

I Point out, for the benefit of the honorable member for Darwin (Mr. Luck), that the promise that was just made by the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Mr. Eric J. Harrison) means absolutely nothing. Irrespective of what representations the Minister may make to the Queensland Government or to the board, under the terms of the agreement the Queensland Government is obliged to deliver sugar to Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth, Fremantle, Hobart and Launceston respectively, and there its obligation ceases. From that point onwards, it becomes the responsibility of the sugar wholesalers in Tasmania to ensure that sufficient supplies of sugar shall be delivered to Devonport, Burnie, and other centres in Tasmania. How then can the Minister allow the honorable member for Darwin to believe that his representations can result in additional supplies of sugar being made available compulsorily to Burnie and Devonport, or, in fact, any centre in Tasmania other than Hobart and Launceston The Minister has indulged in a lot of humbug and the honorable member should persist with his original intention of moving the amendment in order to test the sincerity of the Minister. If the Government believes that appropriate quantities of sugar should be delivered to Burnie and Devonport it should include both centre in the agreement or, alternatively, it should withdraw the bill pending further consultations with the Queensland Government.

talker.role: Vice-President of the Executive Council and Minister for Defence Production
talker.name: HARRISON,Eric John
Mr. ERIC J. HARRISON

talk.start.para: The observations of the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard) would be all right if they were correct and truthful, but they are neither correct nor truthful. At present sugar is being delivered from Melbourne to Burnie and Devonport by the Colonial Sugar Refining Company Limited.
If that is so, why should not those centres be included in the agreement?

There is no need to include them, as I have given the honorable member for Darwin an assurance that representations will made with a view to the delivery of additional quantities of sugar to Burnie and Devonport from Sydney.
Order! Honorable members must remain silent while the Minister is addressing the committee.

When I make a promise of the kind that I have made to the honorable member for Darwin, honorable members generally know that I shall honour it. I am well aware of the circumstances that exist on the north-west of Tasmania. In an attempt to gain party political capital Opposition members are trying to rob the honorable gentleman of the benefits that will accrue to him as the result of the representations that he has made on behalf of his constituents; but they will not succeed in doing so.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: I again raise an important matter that I brought to the attention of the Government two weeks ago. I then urged it to prepare legislation to amend the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act in order to increase the weekly rate of compensation payable under the act to a level that would be commensurate with present living costs. Because of rapid increases of prices, the rate of compensation paid under the act has fallen about £3 a week behind the cost of living. I expected serious consideration to be given to my representations, and had hoped that I should receive a reply from the Government within a fortnight at the very longest. But I have received no acknowledgment of the suggestion even though the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Mr. Eric J. Harrison) announced yesterday a list of bills that the Government proposed to introduce before the end of the current sittings. Therefore, I again ask the Government to give urgent consideration to this matter. The standard rate of compensation should be increased from the present level of £4 a week to about £7 a week. Persons who are receiving compensation because of accidents that they sustained in the service of the Commonwealth are being treated very unjustly. The necessary amending legislation could be introduced next week. I am sure that it would have the approval of every member of this Parliament and would be passed without waste of time. I hope that the Government will produce such a measure at the first opportunity.
